formatting_best_practices.practice: Use line breaks every 2-3 sentences for readability
Bullet points work well (use • or emojis as bullets)
Bold formatting not available, use CAPS sparingly
Links display as previews, place strategically

hashtag_strategy.rule: 3-5 hashtags at the END of post
Research trending tags in your domain
Don't use more than 5 - looks spammy

engagement_tactics.tactic: Post during business hours (9 AM - 5 PM user's timezone)

character_limits.optimal: 125-150 characters for optimal engagement (people read the preview)

formatting_best_practices.practice: First 125 chars are crucial (shown in feed)
Use line breaks for visual rhythm
Consider adding period (.) on separate lines to create space

hashtag_strategy.rule: 10-15 hashtags (can be in first comment to keep caption clean)
Research hashtags before using (avoid banned/spam tags)
Create branded hashtag for your project

engagement_tactics.tactic: Use polls and questions in stories

character_limits.thread: Unlimited tweets in thread, but keep each under 280

formatting_best_practices.practice: Front-load key information (first tweet matters most)
Use line breaks even in short tweets
End threads with CTA or question

hashtag_strategy.rule: Consider not using hashtags at all for casual posts
Place hashtags inline, not at end

engagement_tactics.tactic: Reply to own thread to add context
Engage with replies within first hour

principle.name: show_dont_tell
principle.description: Use specific examples, metrics, and concrete details instead of vague claims

example.bad: We made significant improvements to performance
example.good: Reduced API response time from 500ms to 50ms (10x faster)

principle.name: value_first
principle.description: Lead with benefits and value, not features or technical details

example.bad: We added a new caching layer using Redis
example.good: Your queries now load instantly thanks to smart caching - no more waiting

principle.name: storytelling
principle.description: Frame updates as stories with beginning, middle, and end

structure.end: Where we are now / The impact

principle.name: technical_accessibility
principle.description: Make technical content accessible without dumbing it down

tactics.tactic: Provide context before diving into details
Link to detailed technical docs for depth

principle.name: authenticity
principle.description: Share real challenges, learnings, and behind-the-scenes insights

pitfall.name: Excessive emoji use
pitfall.description: Using too many emojis makes content look unprofessional
pitfall.correct_approach: Use 3-6 emojis strategically for LinkedIn, 5-10 for Instagram, 1-3 for X.com

pitfall.name: Feature listing without context
pitfall.description: Lists of features without explaining WHY they matter
pitfall.correct_approach: For each feature, explain the problem it solves or benefit it provides

pitfall.name: Generic openings
pitfall.description: Starting with "I'm excited to announce" or "I'm pleased to share"
pitfall.correct_approach: Start with the impact, a question, a surprising fact, or jump right into the story

pitfall.name: Hashtag stuffing
pitfall.description: Using 20+ hashtags thinking it increases reach
pitfall.correct_approach: Quality over quantity - use only highly relevant, researched hashtags

pitfall.name: No call-to-action
pitfall.description: Post ends without telling reader what to do next
pitfall.correct_approach: Always end with clear CTA: try it, read more, contribute, share feedback

pitfall.name: Ignoring mobile formatting
pitfall.description: Long paragraphs that look bad on mobile devices
pitfall.correct_approach: Test on mobile - use short paragraphs (2-3 sentences max), add line breaks

guidelines.guideline: Use Brazilian Portuguese, not European Portuguese
Technical terms: often keep English (API, deploy, build)
Informal "você" is acceptable on Instagram, formal for LinkedIn
Use American English spelling (optimize not optimise)

category.name: engagement_optimization
category.item: Hook is compelling in first 2 sentences
